case_title: Mian Ali Nawaz and 20 Others vs Maud Hussain and 28 Others
complaint_summary: The appellants challenged the decision of the Additional Commissioner (Cons.), Sargodha, which accepted the respondents' revision petition and set aside the consolidation scheme of revenue estate Hassu Balail, directing it to be reframed based on ownership entries in the last Jamabandi.
investigation_summary: The consolidation operations in village Hassu Balail began in January 1980, with the final scheme confirmed on 30-08-1981. The Consolidation Officer partitioned Shamlat land attached to nine wells proportionately among shareholders based on the 1924-25 Wajib-ul-Arz. The respondents contested this partition, claiming sole ownership of the land attached to the wells based on entries in earlier settlements and Jamabandis.
judgment_summary: The court ruled that the rights of the parties are governed by the entries in Wajib-ul-Arz prepared during the last settlement, not merely by ownership entries in subsequent Jamabandis. The Additional Commissioner's order was deemed illegal and unsustainable, and the revision petition was allowed, restoring the original consolidation scheme.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition accepted; order of Additional Commissioner set aside.
legal_arguments: The respondents argued that the land attached to the wells was recorded as sole ownership in earlier settlements and Jamabandis.
The appellants contended that the ownership was conditional and subject to partition as per Wajib-ul-Arz entries from the 1880, 1903-04, and 1924-25 settlements.
assets: Land attached to nine wells in village Hassu Balail
sections: Section 13 of the Consolidation of Holdings Ordinance, 1960
Section 39 and Section 41(2) of the Land Revenue Act, 1967
key_issues: Interpretation of Wajib-ul-Arz entries from historical settlements.
Conditional ownership of land attached to wells.

legal_terms.Wajib-ul-Arz: A document prepared during land settlements detailing the rights and obligations of landowners.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the interpretation of historical land settlement records and the conditional ownership of land attached to wells. The court emphasized the precedence of Wajib-ul-Arz entries over subsequent Jamabandi records in determining ownership rights.

summary.issue: Dispute over partition and ownership of shamlat land in village Hassu Balail, Tehsil Shorkot, District Jhang.
summary.background: Consolidation operations began in 1980, and the final scheme was confirmed in 1981. The respondents challenged the partition of shamlat land attached to nine wells, claiming exclusive ownership based on historical records.
key_findings: The land attached to the wells was conditionally granted to the respondents' predecessors in 1880.
The ownership was subject to conditions outlined in the Wajib-ul-Arz of 1880, 1903-4, and 1924-25.
The Additional Commissioner (Cons.) erred in disregarding these conditions and relying solely on the last jamabandi (1974-75).
summary.decision: The revision petition was allowed, and the order of the Additional Commissioner (Cons.), dated 27-9-1982, was set aside.

key_points.land_dispute: Shamlat land measuring 3,019 Kanals, 12 Marlas attached to nine wells.
key_points.historical_context: Ownership conditions were established during British-era settlements in 1880, 1903-4, and 1924-25.
key_points.legal_principle: Rights of parties are governed by Wajib-ul-Arz entries from the last settlement, not just ownership entries in subsequent jamabandis.
